sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Acute otitis media: 400 mg ORALLY once daily for 10 days
  • Bronchitis, chronic, Acute bacterial exacerbation: 400 mg ORALLY once daily for 10 days
  • Pharyngitis: 400 mg ORALLY once daily for 10 days
  • Tonsillitis: 400 mg ORALLY once daily for 10 days

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• safety and efficacy not established in infants less than 6 months old
  • Acute otitis media: (6 months to 12 years old) 9 mg/kg ORALLY once daily for 10 days; MAX, 400 mg/day
  • Acute otitis media: (12 years and older) 400 mg ORALLY once daily for 10 days
  • Bronchitis, chronic, Acute bacterial exacerbation: (12 years and older) 400 mg ORALLY once daily for 10 days
  • Pharyngitis: (6 months to 12 years old) 9 mg/kg ORALLY once daily for 10 days; MAX, 400 mg/day
  • Pharyngitis: (12 years and older) 400 mg ORALLY once daily for 10 days
  • Tonsillitis: (6 months to 12 years old) 9 mg/kg ORALLY once daily for 10 days; MAX, 400 mg/day
  • Tonsillitis: (12 years and older) 400 mg ORALLY once daily for 10 days

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment: CrCl 50 mL/min or greater, usual dose; CrCl 30 to 49 mL/min, 200 mg every 24 hours or 4.5 mg/kg every 24 hours; CrCl 5 to 29 mL/min, 100 mg every 24 hr or 2.25 mg/kg every 24 hr
  • hemodialysis: single dose of 400 mg or 9 mg/kg at the end of each hemodialysis session

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Acute otitis media
  • Bronchitis, chronic, Acute bacterial exacerbation
  • Pharyngitis
  • Tonsillitis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Sexually transmitted infectious disease
  • Urinary tract infectious disease

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to penicillins
  • history of gastrointestinal disease, particularly colitis

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (adults, 3%; children, 4%), Nausea (adults, 4%; children, 0.1% to 1%), Vomiting (adults, 1%; children, 2%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (adults, 3%; children, 0.1% to 1%)
  • Renal:Serum blood urea nitrogen raised (adults, 4%; children, 2%)
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Stevens-Johnson syndrome, Toxic epidermal necrolysis
  • Gastrointestinal:Melena
  • Psychiatric:Psychotic disorder

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Ceftibuten is a semisynthetic cephalosporin antibiotic that is bactericidal to strains of both gram-positive and gram-negative aerobes. It inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to essential target proteins of the bacterial cell wall. It is resistant in the presence of plasmid-mediated beta lactamases but is susceptible to chromosomally-mediated cephalosporinases.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Oral, capsule, adult male: time to peak concentration, 2.6 h +/- 0.9 h
  • Oral, suspension, pediatric: time to peak concentration, 2 h +/- 1 h
  • Bioavailability: (Oral, suspension), undetermined
  • Effect of food: (Oral, capsule), delays Cmax by 1.75 h, decreases Cmax by 18% and decreases AUC by 8%
  • Effect of food: (Oral, suspension, high-fat breakfast), decreases Cmax by 26% and AUC by 17%
  • Effect of food: (Oral, suspension, low-calorie nonfat breakfast), decreases Cmax by 17% and AUC by 12%

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono:
• Vd: (Oral, capsule, adult), 0.21 L/kg +/- 0.03 L/kg
  • Vd: (Oral, suspension, pediatric), 0.5 L/kg +/- 0.2 L/kg
  • Protein binding: 65%

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono: Metabolites: cis-ceftibuten and trans-isomer of ceftibuten

sub.title: Elimination Half Life
sub.mono:
• adult male: (Oral, capsule), 2.4 h +/- 0.2 h
  • pediatric: (Oral, suspension), 2 h +/- 0.6 h
  • anephric: 22.3 h
  • severe renal dysfunction: 13.4 h

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • (suspension) reconstitute with water to a final concentration of 90 mg/5 mL or 180 mg/5 mL; amount of water used to reconstitute the powder and the final concentration depends on the bottle size; store reconstituted suspension refrigerated at 2 to 8 degrees C (36 to 46 degrees F) and use within 14 days
  • (suspension) shake well before measuring the dose
  • (suspension) must be administered at least 2 hours before or 1 hour after a meal

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• fever
  • symptomatic improvement
  • CBC
  • hepatic/renal function
  • previous hypersensitivity to other beta-lactam antibiotics
  • signs of antibiotic-associated diarrhea, other superinfections
  • signs of serum-sickness-like reactions

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Generic
    • Oral Capsule: 400 MG
    • Oral Powder for Suspension: 180 MG/5 ML
  • Cedax
    • Oral Capsule: 400 MG
    • Oral Powder for Suspension: 90 MG/5 ML, 180 MG/5 ML

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
CEPHALOSPORINS
OVERDOSE: Acute ingestion of large doses of cephalosporins may result in nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. Seizures have developed after parenteral overdose. ADVERSE EFFECTS: COMMON: Hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis, may commonly occur with therapy; oral exposures are less likely to cause severe allergic reactions than parenteral exposures. Seizures have also been reported following therapeutic administration. Prolonged prothrombin times, thrombocytopenia, and coagulopathies associated with a qualitative platelet defect and aggregation abnormalities have been reported following IV cephalosporin therapy. Pseudocholelithiasis may follow intravenous administration of ceftriaxone. Several cases of fatal hemolytic reactions following intravenous ceftriaxone therapy have been reported in children with serious hematologic abnormalities.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
CEPHALOSPORINS
  • Decontamination: Generally not indicated in patients with no underlying health problems. Activated charcoal may be necessary for patients with underlying renal insufficiency.
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor renal function, electrolytes, CBC including platelets.
  • Anaphylaxis: Mild to moderate allergic reactions may be treated with antihistamines with or without inhaled beta adrenergic agonists, corticosteroids or epinephrine. Diphenhydramine: ADULTS: 50 mg orally, IV, or IM initially, then 25 to 50 mg orally every 4 to 6 hours for 24 to 72 hours. CHILDREN: 1.25 mg/kg orally, IV, or IM initially, then 5 mg/kg/day orally in 4 divided doses for 24 to 72 hours. Treatment of severe anaphylaxis also includes oxygen supplementation, aggressive airway management, epinephrine, ECG monitoring, and IV fluids.
  • Seizure: IV benzodiazepines, barbiturates
  • Blood coagulation disorder: Vitamin K, fresh frozen plasma
  • Intrathecal injection: Treat seizures with anticonvulsants (benzodiazepines, propofol, phenobarbital); endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation as needed. Keep the patient upright if possible. Immediately drain at least 20 mL CSF; drainage of up to 70 mL has been tolerated in adults. Follow with CSF exchange (remove serial 20 mL aliquots CSF and replace with equivalent volumes of warmed, preservative free normal saline or lactated ringers). For large overdoses, consult a neurosurgeon for placement of a ventricular catheter and begin ventriculolumbar perfusion (infuse warmed preservative free normal saline or lactated ringers through ventricular catheter, drain fluid from lumbar catheter; typical volumes 80 to 150 mL/hr). Dexamethasone 4 mg intravenously every 6 hours to prevent arachnoiditis.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
CEPHALOSPORINS
TOXICITY: Serious toxicity is unlikely following large oral doses of cephalosporins. Crystalluria and hematuria has been described in a 3-year-old boy who ingested 104 mg/kg of cephalexin. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: Varies with agent. CEPHALEXIN: CHILDREN: 25 to 100 milligrams/kilogram/24 hours orally, up to a maximum of 4 grams/day, divided every 6 hours.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Inform diabetic patients that the oral suspension contains 1 gram of sucrose per 5 ml (teaspoon).
  • This drug may cause nausea, vomiting, or headache.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms serum-sickness-like reactions (rash, urticaria, arthralgia, fever, malaise, enlarged lymph nodes).
  • Advise patient to report severe diarrhea and consult healthcare professional prior to taking anti-diarrhea medicine. Other superinfection signs/symptoms should be reported as well.
  • Patient must take the suspension 2 h before or 1 h after a meal.
